Short Description: High-resolution, quasi-global rainfall dataset blending satellite imagery and station data for trend analysis and seasonal drought monitoring
Data Quality Indicators: Validated against station data; uncertainty estimates; provisional data for \~20 days after month end
Metadata Completeness: Spatial/temporal coverage, source, version, units, coordinate system (WGS84)
Update Frequency: Updated within 45 days; provisional data replaced with final
Data Provenance: Satellite + station blend; processing steps documented on [CHC website](https://www.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirps)
Preprocessing Steps: Resampling, masking, unit conversion, missing data handling
Access Methods: FTP/HTTP ([CHC data portal](https://data.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirps/)), [FEWS NET Data Portal](https://earlywarning.usgs.gov/fews), [Google Earth Engine (GEE)](https://developers.google.com/earth-engine/datasets/catalog/UCSB-CHG_CHIRPS_DAILY), R package ([`chirps` on CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/chirps/index.html))
Example Scripts: [Example: Script to Download CHIRPS in R (GitHub)](https://github.com/AdaptationAtlas/hazards/blob/main/R/01_download_data/download_chirps.R)
License/Terms: Open for research and non-commercial use
Integration Challenges: Large file sizes, need for specific libraries (e.g., `netCDF4`, `xarray`), handling provisional data, managing missing data flags
Data Citation: Cite as: "CHIRPS dataset provided by Climate Hazards Group, UCSB"
Benchmarking/Validation Studies: [CHIRPS Validation on CHC website](https://www.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirps/validation), [CHIRPS v2.0: Increased resolution from climate station evaluation (Funk et al., 2015)](https://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2015.66)
Potential Applications (Agroecological): Rainfall pattern analysis, drought monitoring, crop yield modeling, water resource management, agroclimatic zoning, validation of local climate data

Short Description: Reanalysis dataset tailored for agriculture, based on ERA5 but with additional variables and adjustments for agricultural applications
Key Variables: Standard ERA5 variables plus: Evapotranspiration (actual/potential), Soil water content (various depths), Leaf Area Index (LAI), Fraction of Absorbed Photosynthetically Active Radiation (FAPAR), crop-specific indicators
Data Quality Indicators: Model-based, validated against ground observations where possible; uncertainty and bias information in documentation; see [ECMWF documentation](https://confluence.ecmwf.int/display/CKB/ERA5+data+documentation)
Metadata Completeness: Full metadata in GRIB files (variable definitions, units, provenance, coordinate system, version)
Update Frequency: Updated daily with a short delay
Data Provenance: Derived from ERA5 reanalysis; further processed for agricultural relevance; see [AgERA5 documentation](https://www.ecmwf.int/en/forecasts/datasets/reanalysis-datasets/agera5)
Preprocessing Steps: Convert GRIB to NetCDF for easier handling (`cfgrib`, `eccodes`, `xarray`); spatial/temporal subsetting; handle large file sizes; check units/definitions for ag variables
Integration Challenges: Registration required, GRIB format requires specific tools, large data volume, agricultural variable definitions may differ from other datasets
Versioning/Change Log: Versioning and change log available on [CDSE](https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/insitu-gridded-observations-europe) and [ECMWF AgERA5](https://www.ecmwf.int/en/forecasts/datasets/reanalysis-datasets/agera5)
Data Citation: Cite as: "AgERA5 dataset provided by ECMWF and Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S)"
Benchmarking/Validation Studies: [AgERA5: Dataset evaluation and use for crop modeling (ECMWF)](https://www.ecmwf.int/en/elibrary/19899-agera5-dataset-evaluation-and-use-crop-modelling), [AgERA5 technical note (PDF)](https://datastore.copernicus-climate.eu/documents/insitu-gridded-observations-europe/AgERA5_TechNote_v1.0.pdf)
Potential Applications (Agroecological): Crop yield forecasting, irrigation management, pest/disease modeling, land suitability assessment, drought/heat stress monitoring, vegetation dynamics (LAI, FAPAR), water resource management, climate change impact assessment, soil moisture studies
Priority Level: **High (core dataset for agroecology and climate-adaptive agriculture)**

Short Description: High-resolution (\~4 km, 1/24°) monthly global dataset of climate and climatic water balance variables for terrestrial surfaces, combining climatological normals with coarser time-varying data for detailed, temporally consistent records
Key Variables: Precipitation, max/min temperature, wind speed, vapor pressure, vapor pressure deficit, downward shortwave radiation, reference/actual evapotranspiration, climatic water deficit, soil moisture, runoff, snow water equivalent, Palmer Drought Severity Index (PDSI)
Data Quality Indicators: Validated against station and streamflow data; improved mean absolute error and spatial realism; inherits biases from parent datasets (e.g., precipitation bias in mountains)
Metadata Completeness: Metadata available for variables, units, provenance, and grid; NetCDF metadata includes time, lat, lon, variable
Update Frequency: Updated annually when parent datasets become available
Data Provenance: WorldClim v2 (climatology), CRU Ts4.0 and JRA55 (monthly anomalies), climatically aided interpolation; water balance via modified Thornthwaite-Mather model
Preprocessing Steps: Check missing data flags; handle large files; use geospatial tools (netCDF4, xarray, raster, R)
API/Package Links: [Google Earth Engine API Docs](https://developers.google.com/earth-engine/datasets/catalog/IDAHO_EPPSOR_TERRACLIMATE), [Planetary Computer API Docs](https://planetarycomputer.microsoft.com/docs/overview/about/), [THREDDS server access](https://www.climatologylab.org/terraclimate.html), [R package (datazoom.amazonia vignette)](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/datazoom.amazonia/vignettes/TERRACLIMATE.html)
Example Scripts: [Download TerraClimate in Python/R via THREDDS server](https://www.climatologylab.org/terraclimate.html), or use [GEE script example](https://developers.google.com/earth-engine/datasets/catalog/IDAHO_EPPSOR_TERRACLIMATE)
License/Terms: [Public domain (CC0 license)](https://www.climatologylab.org/terraclimate.html); free for research and operational use
Integration Challenges: Large file sizes; requires geospatial software; annual updates; monthly resolution limits capture of short-term extremes; model-derived variables have uncertainties in data-sparse regions
Versioning/Change Log: Versioning/change log not specified; annual updates tracked via parent datasets
Data Citation: Abatzoglou et al. (2018): TerraClimate, a high-resolution global dataset of monthly climate and climatic water balance from 1958–2015. Scientific Data, 5, <https://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2017.191>
Benchmarking/Validation Studies: [Scientific Data article (Abatzoglou et al., 2018)](https://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2017.191), [Climate Data Guide summary](https://climatedataguide.ucar.edu/climate-data/terraclimate-global-high-resolution-gridded-temperature-precipitation-and-other-water)
Potential Applications (Agroecological): Climate trend/variability analysis, drought monitoring, water balance and agricultural risk assessment, crop yield modeling, agroclimatic zoning, ecological/hydrological modeling, validation/downscaling of coarser datasets
Priority Level: **High (core dataset for agroecological and climate-adaptive research)**

Short Description: NASA/JAXA quasi-global (90°S–90°N), high-resolution (0.1° x 0.1°) precipitation estimates by merging GPM satellite constellation data with microwave, infrared, and gauge observations
Temporal Coverage: June 2000–present (updated with latency: Early, Late, Final Runs)
Key Variables: Precipitation rate (mm/hr), accumulated precipitation (mm), error estimates, counts of contributing retrievals
Data Quality Indicators: Validation against global gauge networks; error estimates included; Final Run is highest quality; see [IMERG Algorithm Theoretical Basis Document](https://gpm.nasa.gov/resources/documents/imerg-algorithm-theoretical-basis-document)
Metadata Completeness: NetCDF files include variable/unit metadata, time, lat, lon, run type, version, and error variables
Update Frequency: Half-hourly to monthly, depending on product and run (Early: \~4h latency; Late: \~12h; Final: \~3 months)
Data Provenance: Merges GPM satellite data (microwave/IR sensors) with gauge data; multiple runs differ by latency and data sources; see [IMERG documentation](https://gpm.nasa.gov/data/imerg)
Preprocessing Steps: Handle large files; use netCDF4/xarray/rioxarray (Python) or raster (R); check fill values; aggregate temporally as needed; select appropriate run (Early/Late/Final)
License/Terms: [NASA Data Policy](https://earthdata.nasa.gov/earthdata/earthdata-citation-policy) (open for research/non-commercial use, acknowledge NASA/JAXA/GPM)
Integration Challenges: Large file sizes; software requirements; different runs have different latency/accuracy; missing data flags; only precipitation (no temperature, etc.)
Data Citation: "Huffman, G.J., et al., 2020. NASA Global Precipitation Measurement (GPM) Integrated Multi-satellitE Retrievals for GPM (IMERG), Version 07. NASA's GES DISC. <https://doi.org/10.5067/GPM/IMERG/3B-HH/07>"
Potential Applications (Agroecological): Rainfall pattern analysis, drought monitoring, extreme precipitation event analysis, crop yield modeling, water resource management, agroclimatic zoning, validation of local rainfall data, sub-daily/daily hydrological modeling
Priority Level: **High (core precipitation dataset for agroecological and climate studies)**

Short Description: Long-term, high-resolution rainfall dataset for Africa, blending Meteosat thermal infrared satellite imagery with ground-based rain gauge observations for operational rainfall monitoring and climate risk assessment.
Key Variables: Rainfall/precipitation (mm), soil moisture estimates (for some products)
Data Quality Indicators: Calibrated with ground-based rain gauges; validation and uncertainty assessments published in peer-reviewed literature; quality control flags in data files
Metadata Completeness: NetCDF files include variable names, units, time, lat, lon, version, and quality flags; documentation available on [TAMSAT website](https://www.tamsat.org.uk/)
Update Frequency: Updated regularly as new satellite and gauge data become available
Data Provenance: Derived from Meteosat TIR imagery, calibrated with gauge observations; see [TAMSAT documentation](https://www.tamsat.org.uk/) and publications
Preprocessing Steps: Handle large files; use NetCDF-compatible tools (e.g., xarray, netCDF4, raster); check for missing data flags and quality control layers; aggregate or subset as needed
Access Methods: [TAMSAT Data Portal](https://www.tamsat.org.uk/data/), FTP/HTTP download (see website for latest), may require registration
API/Package Links: No formal public API; use [TAMSAT Data Portal](https://www.tamsat.org.uk/data/) for downloads; process with `xarray`, `netCDF4` (Python), or `raster` (R); check [documentation](https://www.tamsat.org.uk/documentation/) for updates
License/Terms: [Terms of Use](https://www.tamsat.org.uk/terms-of-use/): Free for non-commercial research and educational use; citation required
Integration Challenges: Large file sizes; NetCDF format requires specific tools; access methods may change; rainfall only (no temperature, radiation, etc.); accuracy limited in regions with sparse gauge data
Versioning/Change Log: Versioning and updates noted in file names and [documentation](https://www.tamsat.org.uk/documentation/)
Data Citation: "TAMSAT rainfall dataset, University of Reading. See [TAMSAT website](https://www.tamsat.org.uk/) for citation guidance."
Benchmarking/Validation Studies: [TAMSAT Publications](https://www.tamsat.org.uk/publications/), validation studies listed on the website
Potential Applications (Agroecological): Rainfall pattern analysis, drought monitoring and early warning, agricultural planning, crop yield modeling, water availability assessment, climate risk analysis, validation of other rainfall datasets over Africa
Priority Level: **High (core rainfall dataset for agroecological research in Africa)**

Dataset Name: CHIRTS (Climate Hazards Center InfraRed Temperature with Stations)
Short Description: High-resolution, quasi-global maximum and minimum temperature dataset blending satellite thermal infrared data with ground station observations for climate monitoring and agricultural risk assessment
Data Quality Indicators: Validated against global station data; quality flags and uncertainty estimates included; see [CHIRTS documentation](https://www.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirts)
Metadata Completeness: Metadata includes variable, unit, time, lat, lon, version, and processing details
Update Frequency: Updated as new versions or extensions are released (check CHC website for latest)
Data Provenance: Blends satellite thermal infrared observations with ground station data; processing described in [CHIRTS documentation](https://www.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirts)
Preprocessing Steps: Handle NetCDF files; use xarray, netCDF4 (Python), or raster (R); check for missing data flags
API/Package Links: No formal API; use [CHC data portal](https://www.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirts) for downloads and documentation
Example Scripts: [Example: Download and process CHIRTS in R (GitHub)](https://github.com/AdaptationAtlas/hazards/blob/main/R/01_download_data/download_chirts.R)
License/Terms: Open for research and non-commercial use (see [CHC data use policy](https://www.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirts))
Integration Challenges: Large file sizes; requires geospatial software; limited to temperature variables
Versioning/Change Log: Version history and change log on [CHC website](https://www.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirts)
Data Citation: "CHIRTS dataset provided by Climate Hazards Group, UCSB" (see [CHC citation guidance](https://www.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirts))
Benchmarking/Validation Studies: [Validation and methodology described in CHIRTS documentation](https://www.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirts) and associated peer-reviewed publications
Potential Applications (Agroecological): Heat stress monitoring, crop modeling, climate trend analysis, agricultural risk assessment, drought impact studies, validation of other temperature datasets

Short Description: Fifth generation ECMWF atmospheric reanalysis, providing hourly estimates for a large number of atmospheric, land, and ocean climate variables globally
Spatial Resolution: 0.25° x 0.25° (\~31 km at equator) for atmospheric variables; other variables may differ
Key Variables: Air temperature (various levels), precipitation, surface radiation, wind speed/direction, soil moisture, evaporation, sea surface temperature, sea ice, and more
Data Quality Indicators: Model-based with uncertainties estimated via ensemble; validated against observations; see [ERA5 documentation](https://confluence.ecmwf.int/display/CKB/ERA5:+data+documentation)
Metadata Completeness: Full metadata in GRIB files (variable definitions, units, provenance, coordinate system, version)
Update Frequency: Updated daily with a delay of 2–3 months for final data
Data Provenance: Combines model data with global observations using 4D-Var data assimilation; see [ERA5 documentation](https://confluence.ecmwf.int/display/CKB/ERA5:+data+documentation)\[1\]\[3\]\[5\]
Preprocessing Steps: Use cfgrib/eccodes (Python) for GRIB; convert to NetCDF; subset spatially/temporally; check units/definitions
Access Methods: [Copernicus Data Space Ecosystem (CDSE)](https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/), [ECMWF Data Catalogue (MARS)](https://www.ecmwf.int/en/forecasts/accessing-forecasts/access-archives), [Cloud Platforms (AWS, GCP, Azure)](https://registry.opendata.aws/ecmwf-era5/)
Integration Challenges: Registration required; large dataset volume; GRIB format needs specific tools; high computational demands; complexity of access and format
Versioning/Change Log: Versioning and change log available on [ECMWF documentation](https://confluence.ecmwf.int/display/CKB/ERA5:+data+documentation)
Data Citation: "ERA5 data provided by ECMWF and Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S)"
Potential Applications (Agroecological): Temperature analysis, precipitation/drought monitoring, evapotranspiration, solar radiation, wind patterns, soil moisture, extreme weather, climate change impact studies
Priority Level: **High (core dataset for agroecological and climate research)**

Dataset Name: NASA Earth Exchange Global Daily Downscaled Projections (NEX-GDDP)
Short Description: Global, high-resolution (0.25°) daily climate projections downscaled from CMIP5 and CMIP6 GCMs, including key variables for climate impact studies
Key Variables: tasmin (daily min temperature, K), tasmax (daily max temperature, K), precipitation (kg m?² s?¹)
Data Quality Indicators: Bias-corrected and spatially disaggregated; multiple GCMs/scenarios; see [NEX-GDDP Technical Notes](https://esgf.nccs.nasa.gov/esgdoc/NEX-GDDP_Tech_Note_v0.pdf) (CMIP5), [NEX-GDDP-CMIP6 Technical Note](https://www.nccs.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/NEX-GDDP-CMIP6-Tech_Note_4.pdf)
Metadata Completeness: NetCDF metadata includes variable, unit, scenario, model, time, lat, lon, and processing info
Update Frequency: Dataset is not updated in real time; new versions may be released for CMIP6/other projects
Data Provenance: Downscaled from CMIP5/CMIP6 GCMs using Bias-Correction Spatial Disaggregation (BCSD); see [technical documentation](https://esgf.nccs.nasa.gov/esgdoc/NEX-GDDP_Tech_Note_v0.pdf) (CMIP5), [NEX-GDDP-CMIP6 Technical Note](https://www.nccs.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/NEX-GDDP-CMIP6-Tech_Note_4.pdf)
Preprocessing Steps: Handle large NetCDF files; use xarray, netCDF4, CDO; check for missing data flags; convert units as needed
Example Scripts: [GEE example scripts](https://developers.google.com/earth-engine/datasets/catalog/NASA_NEX-DCP30_ENSEMBLE_STATS), [AWS S3 download example](https://registry.opendata.aws/nex-gddp/), [GitHub script to download data](https://github.com/AdaptationAtlas/hazards/blob/main/R/01_download_data/download_manual_nex_gddpCMIP6.R)
License/Terms: Open for scientific research; not recommended for commercial/engineering use without expert consultation
Integration Challenges: Large file sizes (up to 38 TB for CMIP6), requires technical expertise, limited to temperature/precipitation, projections subject to GCM/downscaling uncertainties
Versioning/Change Log: Versioning and change log available via [NEX-GDDP Technical Notes](https://esgf.nccs.nasa.gov/esgdoc/NEX-GDDP_Tech_Note_v0.pdf) (CMIP5), [NEX-GDDP-CMIP6 Technical Note](https://www.nccs.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/NEX-GDDP-CMIP6-Tech_Note_4.pdf)
Data Citation: "NASA Earth Exchange Global Daily Downscaled Projections (NEX-GDDP)" (see [homepage](https://www.nccs.nasa.gov/services/data-collections/land-based-products/nex-gddp) for citation details)
Potential Applications (Agroecological): Climate risk assessment, crop yield modeling, drought/heat stress analysis, water resource planning, agroclimatic zoning, validation of local climate data
Priority Level: **High (core dataset for climate impact and agroecological research)**

Dataset Name: NASA POWER (Prediction Of Worldwide Energy Resources)
Short Description: Freely available, gridded solar and meteorological datasets derived from NASA satellite observations and climate models for renewable energy, agriculture, and building energy efficiency applications
Temporal Coverage: Varies by parameter; many from 1981 to near-present
Spatial Resolution: 0.5° x 0.5° (\~50 km); some parameters may be higher resolution
Key Variables: Solar radiation (insolation, direct normal irradiance, diffuse horizontal irradiance), surface meteorology (temperature, wind speed/direction, humidity, pressure), precipitation, evapotranspiration, soil moisture (some datasets), cloud cover
Data Quality Indicators: Derived from NASA satellite products and reanalysis; validation and uncertainty information in documentation; see [POWER Documentation](https://power.larc.nasa.gov/docs/)
Metadata Completeness: Metadata included in NetCDF, JSON, and CSV outputs; variable names, units, coordinates, time, and processing info
Update Frequency: Updated regularly as new satellite and reanalysis data are processed
Data Provenance: Combines satellite observations and climate models; see [POWER Documentation](https://power.larc.nasa.gov/docs/) for details
Preprocessing Steps: Handle missing data flags; use appropriate tools for CSV, JSON, NetCDF (e.g., xarray, pandas, netCDF4); check units and spatial/temporal resolution
Access Methods: [POWER Data Access Viewer](https://power.larc.nasa.gov/data-access-viewer/), [POWER API](https://power.larc.nasa.gov/docs/services/api/), direct download (CSV, JSON, NetCDF, GeoJSON)
License/Terms: Public domain; free for use with attribution to NASA/POWER ([citation guidance](https://power.larc.nasa.gov/docs/resources/citation/))
Integration Challenges: 0.5° resolution may be too coarse for local studies; temporal coverage varies by parameter; API requires programming knowledge; handle units and missing data carefully
Potential Applications (Agroecological): Solar resource assessment, crop modeling, irrigation planning, climate risk analysis, energy efficiency studies, agroclimatic zoning, weather-driven agricultural decision support
Priority Level: **High (widely used for agroclimatology and renewable energy)**

Short Description: International coordinated climate modeling effort providing a comprehensive ensemble of global climate projections for understanding past, present, and future climate change
Provider/Source: [World Climate Research Programme (WCRP) WGCM](https://wcrp-cmip.org/cmip-phases/cmip6/), data via [Earth System Grid Federation (ESGF)](https://esgf.llnl.gov/)
Temporal Coverage: Historical: \~1850–present; Projections: up to 2100+ (varies by experiment)
Spatial Resolution: Varies by model (from \~100 km to \~25 km or finer)
Key Variables: Temperature (surface, ocean, etc.), precipitation, radiation, wind, humidity, sea level pressure, sea ice, ocean currents, salinity, soil moisture, runoff, carbon cycle, and more
Data Quality Indicators: Each modeling group provides validation and uncertainty info; ensemble approach allows assessment of robustness; see [Eyring et al., 2016](https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-9-1937-2016)
Metadata Completeness: NetCDF files with CF-compliant metadata (variable/unit, model, experiment, grid, version, etc.)
Update Frequency: Not updated in real time; new experiments released as available
Data Provenance: Data produced by international modeling centers; standardized protocols; see [CMIP6 Overview](https://wcrp-cmip.org/cmip-phases/cmip6/)
Preprocessing Steps: Handle large NetCDF files; use xarray, netCDF4, dask; understand DRS structure; regrid as needed for analysis
License/Terms: Data access and use governed by contributing modeling group terms (see [ESGF Terms](https://esgf.llnl.gov/)), generally free for research/education with attribution
Integration Challenges: Huge data volume; variable model resolutions; complex DRS structure; requires technical expertise; model biases and uncertainties; license terms vary by group
Versioning/Change Log: Versioning and change log per model/experiment; see [CMIP6 DRS](https://pcmdi.llnl.gov/CMIP6/Guide/dataUsers.html)
Potential Applications (Agroecological): Climate change impact assessment, crop suitability, extreme event analysis, adaptation strategy development, regional downscaling, climate risk analysis
Priority Level: **High (core dataset for climate and agroecological research)**
